reviewText: Much to my chagrin, Prisoner: Cell Block H went out of print on VHS, well over a decade ago. I can't imagine why, it's a groundbreaking cult hit! It seems they were only available on american video a short while, then became obscure & unattainable. Fortunately I scour around every now & then & discovered the old MPI releases were available from select marketplace sellers, brand new & factory sealed, so I was at long last able to get the episodes I couldn't back then.The DVD release of sets 1 & 2 only contain select episodes. One of which has episodes 1-4: the beginnning, then skips to a much higher episode number, as they're unfortunately out-of-sequence in A&E;'s DVD release, so I ordered volume 3, immediately, which picks up where episode 4 leaves off, when Meg Jackson's husband is killed. Volumes 1-6 of MPI became helpful to have in my collection, as volume 3 (episodes 5 & 6), volume 4 (episodes 7 & 8), volume 5 (episodes 9 & 10), volume 6 (episodes 11 & 12)... again, episodes 5-12 are not contained on the DVD, so it makes for a great carry-over & puts the episodes in sequence from those episodes which aren't offered on the DVD sets.Hopefully, one day Prisoner: Cell Block H will get the correct DVD treatement & some of the other fans will become more vocal in letting distributors know we don't want handpicked episodes out of sequence, we want the proper installments from the very inception of this excellent series. We wants episode 1 right through to episode 692, when The Freak is finally locked up.I couldn't recommend Prisoner more to fans of good cult tv, or prison drama without all the hype of most american fare these days.
summary: I Finally have these long out-of-print MPI Prisoner Videos

reviewText: Prisoner Cell Block H was a hit TV series , from Australia , from 1979 to 1986.It revolves around the lives of the inmates and wardens of Wentworth Prison.Quite a compelling series , both amusing and filled with a lot of violence and feuds between prisoners and prisoners or prisoners and wardens.Fun characterization , you will always want to see what Bea , Monica, Lizzie , Noelene , Lynne, Karen etc are up to next. It also explores the loneliness and despair of prison life
summary: The ins and outs of Wentworth Prison
Title: N/A

reviewText: This brings back memories of me as a young teen staying up late to savour the latest weekly episode of a classic Australian serial. After seeing my first episode I was surprised that it was around 10 years old by the time it was aired on UK screens.The 32 episodes included in this boxset are a fantastic treat for any Prisoner fan and would probably appeal to fans of any other late 70s early 80s Australian soap due to the wealth of guest artists that seem to end up inside or are involved with those in the Wentworth Detention Centre.Relive the classic confrontations between liberal Governor Erica Davidson (Patsy King) and her acid-tongued sadistic deputy Vera Bennett (Fiona Spence). Meander through those cries of innocence from Lynn Warner (Kerry Armstrong). How will top dog Bea Smith (Val Lehman) and Mum Brooks (Mary Ward) adjust to their life outside Wentworth? How about the drug-smuggling relative (Sally Cahill) of a staff member behind bars to spice up the action. Enjoy the criminally lax security of Wentworth in all it's glory when old lag Lizzie Birdsworth (Sheila Florance), biker Franky Doyle (Carol Burns) and Doreen Anderson (Colette Mann) breakout. Helen Masters (Louise Pajo) and her experience with the women, not forgetting the food. Intrigue when a corrupt ex-officer (Kirsty Child) is re-acquanited with a staff member resulting in the boxset cliffhanger.The dodgy incidental music, the limited use of sets, the dodgy camerawork, Boom!, the flares, the sideburns, Erica's dresses, Catherine Roberts....Aaaagh - it really is so bad at times that it is truly wonderful.All 32 episodes are complete in their original format with no speaking over the end credits as was often the case on UK ITV and Five screenings.And check out the first few episodes to see a very red-haired Anne Charleston (Anne later went onto great fame as Madge in Neighbours) in her outrageous outfit while leaving the Pizza Hut. Classic!
summary: It's Melbourne 1979 and we are about to enter the world of the Wentworth Detention Centre for women
